definition: lit. two segments with a single cut (idiom)/fig. to make a clean break (idiom)
one/1/single/a (article)/as soon as/entire/whole/all/throughout/"one" radical in Chinese characters (Kangxi radical 1)/also pr. [yao1] for greater clarity when spelling out numbers digit by digit
knife/blade/single-edged sword/cutlass/CL:把[ba3]/(slang) dollar (loanword)/classifier for sets of one hundred sheets (of paper)/classifier for knife cuts or stabs
surname Dao
two/both/some/a few/tael, unit of weight equal to 50 grams (modern) or 1⁄16 of a catty 斤[jin1] (old)
to break/to snap/to cut off/to give up or abstain from sth/to judge/(usu. used in the negative) absolutely/definitely/decidedly

sentences.english: If you dare to use that word in my hearing again, we part brass rags .
sentences.chinese: 如果你敢于当着我的面说那个词，咱俩就一刀两断。

sentences.english: Breaking with traditional gender patterns is especially important when children are involved.
sentences.chinese: 当孩子卷进来时，与传统性伴侣一刀两断非常重要。

sentences.english: After the quarrel she gave her boyfriend the gate.
sentences.chinese: 吵嘴后她和男朋友一刀两断了。

sentences.english: You'd better break off with him.
Why burn a bridge to someone who could help you later? That's just stupid.
sentences.chinese: 跟别人一刀两断以后谁还肯帮助你？那真是傻。

sentences.english: But the promised "clean break" from the past is not - yet - out of reach.
sentences.chinese: 不过他所承诺的与过去”一刀两断“并非遥不可及。

sentences.english: He resolved to make a fresh start, and throw off undesirable acquaintances.
sentences.chinese: 他下决心重新开始，和那些狐朋狗友们一刀两断。

sentences.english: I want to make a clean sweep of everything I've learnt and start afresh.
sentences.chinese: 我要和以前学的那些玩艺儿一刀两断，一切从头开始。

definition: to split up/to break all ties
to rip one's robe as a sign of repudiating a sworn brotherhood (idiom)/to break all friendly ties
to bring to a conclusion/to settle (a dispute)/to do away with (oneself)/to break off (a relationship)/resolution (of a problem)
lit. lotus roots may break, but the fiber remains joined (idiom); lovers part, but still long for one another
(of marriage or business partners) to break up (idiom)/to separate
to rupture/to burst open/to break/to break off relations with/a rupture
to cut off/to chop sth in half
lit. quick sword cuts through tangled hemp (idiom); decisive action in a complex situation/cutting the Gordian knot
see 撕破臉|撕破脸[si1 po4 lian3]
to write off at one stroke
hopelessly muddled/impossible to unravel
the two cannot exist together (idiom); irreconcilable differences/incompatible standpoints
to fall out with sb/to become hostile
lit. either the fish dies or the net splits/a life and death struggle (idiom)
to have an acrimonious falling-out/to shed all pretense of cordiality/to tear into each other
to break off relations/to break with sb
